block.p: Clinton Orders Oil Released From Emergency Reserve President Clinton ordered the release of 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's emergency reserve over the next month, only a day after Vice President Al Gore injected the issue into the presidential campaign. The move could stall or even reverse the surge in home heating oil and gasoline prices. But analysts said that there were no guarantees that consumers would benefit and that the decision did nothing to address the underlying issue of how to bring energy supply into line with demand over the long run. Administration officials said they acted primarily because inventories of heating oil on the East Coast had fallen to worrisomely low levels, raising the risk of shortages should the winter be particularly cold or long. [Page A1.]

Clinton Orders Oil Released From Emergency Reserve President Clinton ordered the release of 30 million barrels of oil from the nation's emergency reserve over the next month, only a day after Vice President Al Gore injected the issue into the presidential campaign. The move could stall or even reverse the surge in home heating oil and gasoline prices. But analysts said that there were no guarantees that consumers would benefit and that the decision did nothing to address the underlying issue of how to bring energy supply into line with demand over the long run. Administration officials said they acted primarily because inventories of heating oil on the East Coast had fallen to worrisomely low levels, raising the risk of shortages should the winter be particularly cold or long. [Page A1.]

In deciding to release oil from the nation's strategic reserves, President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore exploited one of the major perks of incumbency, the power to move oil and markets. News Analysis. [A1.]

Central Banks Move to Help Euro The central banks of the United States, Japan and European countries intervened in currency markets and bought billions of euros to support the battered currency. [A1.]
A stronger euro could help the bottom lines of multinational corporations that export products to Europe. [C4.]

Major Auction Houses Settle Case The world's largest auction houses, Sotheby's and Christie's, tentatively agreed to pay $512 million to settle claims that they cheated buyers and sellers in a price-fixing scheme that dates to 1992. [A1.]

AOL-Time Warner Concerns Persist Remedies proposed by Time Warner and America Online to allay concerns of European antitrust regulators about their proposed $165 billion merger have failed to sway opponents of the deal in the music and Internet industries and among consumer organizations, making it unlikely the regulators will accept them without substantive change. [C2.]

S.E.C. Accuses Frankel of Fraud Martin R. Frankel, the financier facing federal criminal charges in an insurance scandal, has been named in a fraud complaint by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The agency also filed a complaint against John A. Hackney, accusing him of helping Mr. Frankel to loot millions of dollars from 10 insurance companies. [C15.]

Pilots Ordered to Pay Airline The pilots' union at American Airlines was ordered by a federal court to pay the airline $45.5 million in damages for ignoring a judge's order to end a 1999 work stoppage. [C5.]

Washington Post Names Publisher Donald E. Graham announced he was stepping down after 21 years as publisher of The Washington Post and named a longtime assistant, Boisfeuillet Jones Jr., as publisher and president of the newspaper. [C2.]

Hewlett-Packard Names Executive Hewlett-Packard named Carly Fiorina, its president and chief executive, to the additional post of chairwoman, and said it planned to buy back up to $1 billion of its shares. [C3.]

Toyota Expects Stronger Results Toyota, Japan's leading automaker, said that it was likely to report higher earnings for the first half of its fiscal year than it had anticipated as sales were stronger than expected in North America and Europe. [C3.]

Failure of Daewoo Talks Hurt Banks South Korea will have to spend $44 billion more to prop up domestic banks, which were hit hard by the collapse of efforts last week to sell the nearly bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company, the nation's finance minister said. [C3.]
